description: Borrowed from Middle French desgouster, from Old French desgouster (“to put off one's appetite”), from des- (“dis-”) + gouster, goster (“to taste”), from Latin gustus (“a tasting”).

entries.meaning: An intense dislike or loathing someone feels for something bad or nasty.
examples: With an air of disgust, she stormed out of the room.

verbs.description: disgust (third-person singular simple present disgusts, present participle disgusting, simple past and past participle disgusted)

entries.meaning: To cause an intense dislike for something.
examples: It disgusts me to see her chew with her mouth open.
